description: From Middle French sanction, from Latin sanctio.

entries.meaning: An approval, by an authority, generally one that makes something valid.
examples: The whalers had been operating in the contested waters off the island with sanction from the Japanese government.

entries.meaning: A penalty, punishment, or some coercive measure, intended to ensure compliance; especially one adopted by several nations, or by an international body.
examples: The United States enacted a new round of sanctions against the apartheid regime of South Africa.

entries.meaning: A law, treaty, or contract, or a clause within a law, treaty, or contract, specifying any of the above.

verbs.description: sanction (third-person singular simple present sanctions, present participle sanctioning, simple past and past participle sanctioned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give official authorization or approval to; to countenance.
examples: Many of the most earnest Protestants were business men, to whom lending money at interest was essential. Consequently first Calvin, and then other Protestant divines, sanctioned interest.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To penalize (a state etc.) with sanctions.
